w:r.w:t: The structural pattern of the app (tracker, tool, AI assistant, community, game, etc.). It defines the core value delivery model.
Different archetypes have different retention curves and monetisation norms.
Look at top 20 apps in your niche.
Categorise yours by dominant behaviour loop.
No external tool needed — it’s classification.
Competitor set size (what is it and how do I find out?)
How many apps are directly competing for the same user/problem.
Count relevant direct substitutes in top 50 results.
to filter by category + revenue band.
How close your product is to top revenue apps in the niche.
Or use ASO tools to compare shared keywords.
Evidence that people are actively searching/downloading in this niche.
High combined downloads + strong keyword volume = strong demand.
Is the niche expanding, stable, or shrinking?
Compare last 6–12 months revenue/download data in Sensor Tower/data.ai.
How hard it is to displace existing leaders.
Review counts (if leaders have 100k+ reviews, barrier is high).
If top 3 control 60%+ revenue → high intensity.
Can you profitably run ads to acquire users?
Estimate CPI via ad intelligence tools.
Gap between keyword demand and competition.
Count how many keywords have weak ranking apps.
Demand spikes at certain times of year.
Monthly download fluctuations in market data.
Fitness spikes in January, exams in May/June, etc.
How often the user experiences the problem.
Willingness to pay observed in competitors.
Can user experience value in first session?
Can you describe the repeat loop in one sentence?
Do competitors have strong session-based repetition?
Does usage involve social proof or competition?
Apps with visible comparison loops retain longer.
High trust = harder acquisition, but higher switching cost.
Apps that show value before paywall convert better.
Most subscription leaders use annual discount anchor.
Using higher reference price to make offer attractive.
Compare screenshot quality to top 10 competitors.
Ability to drive installs from other owned apps.
The one metric that determines success.
Define ONE north star metric before launch.
